Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the global food demand is expected to increase by 50% by 2030. This study quantifies the impact of climate change on maize production and trade, and it highlights the vulnerability of the world’s maize-producing and -exporting countries to climate change. Our results show that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year increases from 0% to 7% under 2 °C warming and to 86% under 4 °C warming. This study also shows that the coefficient of variation of maize yields increases to values much larger than present-day values, and it underscores the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance. These results have important implications for global food security and international grain trade. They also highlight the need for a global effort to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level differences in diet. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species of African LMH. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers. Grass consumption inferred from DNA sequence relative read abundance ranged from >99% (plains zebra) to <1% (dik-dik). Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. Nonetheless, diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the brain. We also show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn aggregates in a mouse model of MSA. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising drug to slow down the progression of MSA. This would be the first treatment for MSA, which currently has no curative or disease-modifying therapy. Our results also suggest that caspase-1 could be a potential therapeutic target in synucleinopathies. This is the first study to show that caspase-1 is able to cleave α-syn at its C terminus, thereby promoting its aggregation. This finding could have implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies for synucleinopathies.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social groups, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchy is largely unknown. The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. We also introduce a new class of stable neural networks, which we call fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs). We prove that FIRENETs are stable and that only a small number of layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in severing actin filaments. However, how it does so is not well understood. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques, coupled to microfluidics, to study the action of ADF in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF binds to filaments in a mechanical-dependent manner, and that this binding enhances severing. We propose that this mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings have implications for understanding severing in cells and for developing new strategies to treat diseases caused by actin filament networks. They also provide a general framework for understanding the action of other proteins that bind to filaments in a mechanical-dependent manner. This framework can be used to predict the effects of mechanical forces on the action of such proteins.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in soft drinks and other foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. The results also suggest that the effects of fructose on brain and behavior may be modified by the presence of glucose. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on health and for the development of strategies to reduce consumption of these beverages. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, from the north to the south, and from the east to the west. We find that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement of Madagascar happened independently from Africa and Asia, suggesting that Madagascar was settled by a population that was already admixed. In addition, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive picture of the history of Madagascar. It also provides a reference for the genomic diversity of the Malagasy population, which is a unique population in the world. This reference will be useful for the study of human evolution and the study of human diseases in Madagascar. It will also be useful for the study of human diversity in general.

We show that people’s emotions can be transferred to others via social networks. This work has implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society, and for the design of social media.

The presence of RNA modifications in coding regions of messenger RNAs (mRNAs) has been known for decades, but their impact on mRNA function has only recently been appreciated. We show that the presence of one of the most common modifications, pseudouridine (Ψ), in an mRNA codon can have a profound effect on translation. We find that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA can slow translation, increase the rate of near-cognate amino acid addition, and increase the rate of peptide synthesis. These findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can have a significant impact on the rate of protein synthesis. This is an important finding for understanding the function of Ψ in the context of mRNA stability and translation. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of health and behavioral outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone. These associations are robust to a range of sensitivity analyses, and the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. These findings have implications for public health and for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a well-known phenomenon, but the underlying drivers of this pattern have been difficult to test quantitatively. Here, we use a combination of comparative phylogenetic analysis and examination of the fossil record to show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms. Water-dwelling mammals are driven and confined to larger body sizes by the strict energetic demands of the aquatic medium. This work provides a quantitative framework for understanding the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals. It also has implications for understanding the evolution of body size in other taxa that inhabit complex, nonterrestrial environments. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

Rhinovirus, the common cold virus, replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. To understand the mechanism of temperature-dependent growth, we compared the transcriptional response of primary mouse airway epithelial cells infected with mouse-adapted rhinovirus 1B at 33 °C vs. 37 °C. We found that mouse airway cells infected with rhinovirus exhibited a striking enrichment in expression of antiviral defense response genes at 37 °C relative to 33 °C, which correlated with significantly higher expression levels of type I and type III IFN genes and ISGs at 37 °C. These findings demonstrate that in mouse airway cells, rhinovirus replicates preferentially at nasal cavity temperature due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. This study provides insight into the molecular basis of the temperature-dependent growth of rhinovirus, which is the most prevalent cause of the common cold. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

Bacteria use a variety of sensing systems to respond to environmental signals. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to detect surfaces. This mechanosensory system is important for the pathogen to attach to surfaces and to promote the production of virulence factors and biofilm formation. The type IV pili-mediated surface sensing system is a unique example of a mechanochemical system that measures the mechanical activity of the cell surface, and it is likely to be a common sensing mechanism in bacteria.

The global spread of pesticides has led to a substantial increase in the number of surface water samples exceeding the legally accepted regulatory threshold levels. This study provides a comprehensive metaanalysis of 838 peer-reviewed studies that evaluates the global risk of pesticide contamination of surface waters. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions. This study is a step toward a better understanding of the global pesticide problem and its consequences for the environment and human health.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the ecology of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to SARS-CoV-2 infection. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 can be transmitted between deer. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a robust and proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This study highlights the need for a better understanding of the ecology of SARS-CoV-2. (Show more)

The hydropower industry has been building dams in the developing world for decades. The proliferation of large dams in the Mekong River Basin, the Amazon River Basin, and the Congo River Basin is a recent phenomenon. The same problems are being repeated: disrupting river ecology, deforestation, losing aquatic and terrestrial biodiversity, releasing substantial greenhouse gases, displacing thousands of people, and altering people’s livelihoods plus affecting the food systems, water quality, and agriculture near them. This paper studies the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) peptide is the primary component of the plaques that are the hallmark of the disease. However, the role of Aβ in the initiation of the AD-related immune response is still unclear. Here, we show that Aβ-burdened neurons are the primary source of inflammatory factors, which may precede the formation of Aβ plaques. Our findings suggest that the Aβ-burdened neuron may be a critical player in the AD pathogenesis, and may represent a therapeutic target for the treatment of the disease. This study also provides a unique insight into the role of the intraneuronal Aβ accumulation in the AD-related immune response.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is still missing. We present a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that the exploitation of chickens was widespread and economically important in the ancient world. Our results suggest that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe predates the earliest evidence in the Near East by at least a century.

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and it is not yet clear how it proceeds. We have developed a method that allows us to study the folding of a large protein at high structural resolution. We have used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a protein that has been studied extensively. We find that the folding proceeds in distinct steps, and that the steps are adjacent in the sequence. This is the first time that this has been observed in a large protein. This is an important step in understanding the folding process. It also suggests that the steps are not necessarily adjacent in the native protein.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the cellular conditions that enable this accumulation are not well understood. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to remove the nucleoside monophosphate cap from mRNA, also removes the Np4 cap. We also show that this enzyme prefers to remove capped RNAs over their capped counterparts, and that it does so by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to remove the 5′ termini of other RNAs. These findings suggest that RppH may be a critical component of the machinery that regulates the expression of genes in response to stress. Understanding how this enzyme functions could lead to the development of new strategies for controlling gene expression. (Read more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with a high mortality rate. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. Here, we show that arginine, a key amino acid, is essential for the maintenance of T cell function and proliferation during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a metabolic product of arginine, is more effective than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation. These results suggest that citrulline could be a promising therapeutic strategy to improve the outcome of sepsis patients. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. (Show more)

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to better understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. They also provide a baseline for future studies on the impact of human activities on the biosphere. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) that is continuous in contrast to all known models of SOC. We show that our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model (cf. Turing reaction-diffusion model), requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a promising material for electronic and photonic applications, but its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects. In this work, we show that strain engineering can be used to control the electronic and optical properties of diamond. We show that strain can be used to tune the bandgap of diamond, and that strain can be used to control the stability of diamond. These findings can be used to tailor the properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

However, the plant immune system is not perfect, and it can be overcome by some pathogens. This work describes the antifungal activity of a unique, highly dynamic, and structurally defined NCR peptide, which is a member of a large family of nodule-specific peptides in the model legume Medicago truncatula. The antifungal activity of the peptide is attributed to its ability to bind to and disrupt the cell wall of the fungal pathogen. The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the processes of evolution and development. In this study, we use proteomics to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between male and female reproductive tracts. We show that the sperm proteome undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating, and they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome following 4 d of storage in the female reproductive tract. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. We show that force application to platelets switches the VWF A1 domain to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. The human microbiome is a vast ecosystem of microorganisms that is intimately connected to human health. The human virome is a subset of the microbiome that has been largely ignored, despite the fact that it is likely to be just as important to human health as the bacteriome. This study is the first to comprehensively catalog the human virome, and to show that it is a major contributor to human disease. The results are expected to have a major impact on the field of human microbiome research.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is mainly due to the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to overcome this conundrum. The HSRL can simultaneously profile aerosol and cloud properties, especially cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the scientific potential of this instrument by conducting a case study over Beijing. The observations show that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This is a significant contribution to the field of climate science. We expect this instrument to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations in the future.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth today is inferred to be ∼15 °C, but the temperature of the Earth’s surface in the past is unknown. We have developed a method to determine the temperature of the Earth’s surface in the past by studying the thermostability of enzymes. We have determined that the temperature of the Earth’s surface in the past was ∼65–80 °C. This finding is consistent with previous temperature estimates based on isotopic evidence.

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow in the body. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We induced C-type inactivation in BK channels and studied the relationship between activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery. Diamond is a promising material for applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is a semiconductor with a wide bandgap, but its electronic properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under strain, without the need for doping. We also show that diamond can be used as a strain sensor, and that strain can be used to control the electronic and optical properties of diamond. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This article is protected by copyright. Influenza virus infection is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza virus outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. While low ambient humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that inhalation of dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. Whether and how this merge operation is implemented in the brain is unknown. Here, we show that high-gamma power in multiple superior temporal and inferior frontal regions increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words can be merged into phrases. This merge operation is consistent with a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental step in the construction of meaning.

Axin is a key component of the Wnt signaling pathway, which is important for development and homeostasis. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are regulated differently, which may be important for tissue-specific responses.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. In this study, we show that stimulation of LH neurons causes rapid vigorous eating in sated animals. We also show that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety. Instead, we show that stimulation of LH neurons activates a circuit that promotes overeating. This circuit is located in the brainstem, where it projects to the nucleus accumbens, a brain region that is involved in the regulation of feeding and reward. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of feeding and may contribute to the understanding of obesity. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The Peruvian Amazon is one of the most deforested regions in the world, and the Peruvian government has made forest monitoring a priority. We study a community-based monitoring program that was randomly assigned to 39 of 76 communities in the Peruvian Amazon. Our results suggest that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Data from monitoring records and community surveys provide evidence about how the program may affect forest outcomes. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management. This approach could be applied in other regions where deforestation is driven by a combination of economic and political factors.

Animals have evolved a wide range of hearing organs, but they are all part of the body. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body, because its web acts as an acoustic antenna. We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. The benefits of reducing air pollution are greatest in the most populous regions of the world, where the largest number of deaths are attributable to outdoor air pollution.

The role of ALK/Ltk in neural crest development has been studied in detail in the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster and the mouse mouse. Here, we show that the zebrafish ALK/Ltk signaling pathway is functional and that the zebrafish ALKALs are required for the development of iridophores, pigment cells of the zebrafish lateral line system. Our results provide in vivo evidence of (i) activation of ALK/Ltk family receptors by ALKALs and (ii) an involvement of these ligand–receptor complexes in neural crest development. Our findings are important for understanding the role of ALK/Ltk in human development and disease. They also provide a model system for studying the role of ALK/Ltk in human development and disease.

The plague bacterium Yersinia pestis has been responsible for devastating outbreaks throughout human history. The earliest Y. pestis genomes recovered from the Neolithic period have revealed key evolutionary steps that led to its emergence from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor. However, the number of genomes from this period are too few to explore its diversity during this critical period of development. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes dating to 5,000 to 2,500 y BP from a wide geographic expanse across Eurasia. Our results suggest a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents throughout this period, a trend not observed in other pathogens for which ancient genomes are available. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This work is important for understanding the origins of plague and its impact on human history. It also has implications for the spread of disease in the modern world. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. The fate of carbon (C) in agricultural soils is a critical component of the global carbon cycle and climate change. In the United States, the conversion of grasslands to crop production has led to the release of massive amounts of C to the atmosphere. We show that soil health management practices can mitigate this trend and that the use of diverse, rotationally grazed pastures can increase soil C storage on agricultural lands. These results highlight the potential of grasslands to sequester C and provide a pathway for climate-smart agriculture. This work also highlights the importance of long-term, multidisciplinary studies to understand the complex interactions between management, soil, and the environment. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and cause disease outbreaks. We then created a web tool, SpillOver, that allows users to explore the results and to prioritize their own research and public health interventions. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is the reward that most plants offer to pollinators for visitation. One of the main rewards plants offer to pollinators for visitation is nectar. Nesocodon mauritianus (Campanulaceae) produces a blood-red nectar that has been proposed to serve as a visual attractant for pollinator visitation. Here, we show that the nectar’s red color is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid termed nesocodin. We identify a convergent evolution of this trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, Jaltomata herrerae and Nesocodon. We also provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait in two distantly related species. The genetic structure of modern Europeans is strongly correlated with geography, but the processes that shaped it are still poorly understood. We present a genome analysis of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between 490 and 650 AD. Our results indicate that they had a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that they also differed in visible characteristics. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings are important for understanding the origins of MERS-CoV and for preventing future bat-to-human spillover events. This article is protected by copyright.

DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template in eukaryotes. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In S. cerevisiae, the extreme stability of the pol δ holoenzyme ensures that every nucleobase within an Okazaki fragment is faithfully duplicated before dissociation. However, the stability of the human pol δ holoenzyme is unknown. We designed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Surprisingly, the results indicate that human pol δ maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique perspective on the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for lagging strand synthesis in humans. It also provides a unique system to study the role of PCNA in the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. This system can be extended to study the role of PCNA in other systems where the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is important

The origin of life is one of the most important questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of genetically encoded proteins, ancestral organisms contained RNA genes that were replicated by an RNA polymerase ribozyme. In the laboratory, RNA polymerase ribozymes can now be evolved to synthesize functional RNA molecules from an RNA template, and can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work is a major step toward the realization of the RNA world.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a critical factor in the success of urban policy.

The clinical characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients were analyzed, and the therapeutic effect of tocilizumab was evaluated. The results showed that tocilizumab could improve the clinical symptoms and reduce mortality in severe and critical COVID-19 patients. It is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its excess can be toxic. The ability of fungi to sequester copper in the form of isocyanide-containing natural products is described here. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This work provides a new perspective on the role of isocyanide-containing natural products in the biology of fungi and their potential as antimicrobial agents. This work also provides a model for the evolution of isocyanide-containing natural products in fungi. The discovery of copper-binding isocyanide-containing natural products in fungi is a significant advance in our understanding of the evolution and function of these compounds. The presence of tridymite, a high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of SiO2, in a sedimentary mudstone at Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it is a product of high-temperature, high-pressure metamorphism. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary mudstone is also significant because it is a product of diagenesis, not volcanism. The diagenesis of high-SiO2 glass and/or precipitated silica in a sedimentary environment is also significant because it is a process that could have occurred on Earth in the past and could occur in the future on Earth and on other planets and moons.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in response to climate warming, and that this change is already affecting the performance of forests. Our findings can inform land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this subset of cells is unclear. Here we show that the development of colitis requires the transition of a subset of Th17 cells to Th1-like cells, and that this process requires the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. Th17 cells can also provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. Understanding the functional significance of these mechanisms may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for treating inflammatory bowel disease. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, the cells that control voluntary muscle movement. The disease is progressive, and death occurs within 3 to 5 y. The disease is fatal, and there is a need to develop disease models and identify therapeutics. We now report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living ALS patients. This will enable high-throughput drug screening and identification of disease-modifying therapies. This method will also enable rapid screening of drugs for toxicity to motor neurons and astrocytes, which are the cells that cause the disease. This will be a major advance in ALS research.

The gut microbiota of ticks is a complex community that is essential for the transmission of pathogens to vertebrate hosts. Here, we show that the bacterium Anaplasma phagocytophilum modifies the gut microbiota of the vector tick, Ixodes scapularis, to more efficiently colonize the tick. We demonstrate that Anaplasma modifies the tick microbiota by inducing the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the integrity of the peritrophic matrix and gut barrier. We also show that antifreeze glycoprotein binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insight into the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an antibacterial protein from an arthropod to more effectively colonize the vector. This work also highlights the importance of the gut microbiota in the transmission of pathogens between vectors and hosts. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds, as it is associated with the loss of the hind limbs and the transition to flight. The earliest members of the clade Pygostylia (birds with a short tail ending in a compound bone termed “pygostyle”) are critical for understanding the origin of the modern avian bauplan. Here, we describe a new basal member of the Pygostylia, Jinguofortis perplexus, which adds important information about the evolution of early members of the short-tailed bird group. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. We show that the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate system. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of them have the ability to change color. This ability is important for animals to adapt to their environment, and it is also important for animals to avoid being eaten. In this study, we show that the ability to change color has evolved multiple times during vertebrate evolution, and that the ability to change color is important for animals to avoid being eaten.

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and is associated with the maintenance of cancer stem cells, which are responsible for tumor initiation and metastasis. We report that hypoxia induces expression of the m6A demethylase AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia in breast cancer cells, and is required for the maintenance of breast cancer stem cells. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible is one of the most important books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical to understanding the causes and consequences of extinction and recovery. The age model presented here is based on a precise age model for the extinction and a detailed analysis of the carbon cycle response to the perturbation. The age model is consistent with the hypothesis that the extinction was triggered by a combination of volcanism, carbon cycle disruption, and climate change. The carbon cycle response is consistent with the hypothesis that the extinction was followed by a period of ecosystem reorganization. The age model presented here provides a starting point for a more detailed analysis of the extinction and recovery dynamics. (Less)

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a member of the orphan nuclear receptor superfamily, which is involved in various biological processes, such as metabolism, cancer, and circadian rhythm. Here, we generate intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient (RORαΔIEC) mice and find that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the receptor ACE2 at 3.4 Å resolution. We find that the D614G mutation has led to a more open conformation of the spike, which may facilitate binding to the receptor. This work provides a foundation for understanding the impact of the D614G mutation on the structure and function of the spike and will be important for the development of future vaccine and therapeutic strategies.

We study the existence of equilibria in repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs. We show that, under mild assumptions, every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an equilibrium, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. The result is a generalization of the classical result of Moulin and Zamir (1982) to the case of Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that, in the absence of the pandemic, life expectancy at birth would have been 78.65 y in 2020, a decline of 1.13 y, compared with the actual 2020 death toll. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y.

The chemical properties of atoms are central to chemistry, and they are also important in many other fields, such as physics, biology, and geology. In this paper, we show that pressure can change the chemical properties of atoms, and that these changes can be predicted and explained. This work is important for chemistry, physics, and geology.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, which can have important consequences for the global carbon cycle. However, the effects of climate change on fire activity are uncertain, and the effects of human ignitions are often overlooked. We show that, in some regions, human ignitions can reduce the effects of climate change on global warming. This is especially true under lower emissions scenarios, which are more likely to be realized. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the global carbon cycle and the need to consider the effects of both climate and human activities on fire regimes. This is especially important in fire-dependent ecosystems, where fire suppression can have negative consequences for biodiversity and ecosystem function. Our study also highlights the need for improved fire observations and fire emissions estimates. This is especially important in the tropics, where fire is a major source of uncertainty in global carbon cycle models.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic relationships. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan, chitin, to its symbiotic bacterium, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm. This glycan is required for the maturation of the symbiotic organ, which is used for bioluminescence. We propose that this strategy is used by other hosts to regulate the activities of their symbionts. This work provides a new perspective on the role of glycans in the regulation of symbiosis. Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We draw on advances in theoretical machine learning to integrate topic modeling and word embedding, capitalizing on their distinct capabilities. Our method can be applied to any corpus of text, and we illustrate it with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We hope it will be useful to researchers and practitioners in many fields. We also hope it will inspire others to apply these methods to their own data.

The second plague pandemic, which started in the 14th century, was the consequence of the introduction of Yersinia pestis, a bacterium that causes plague. The pandemic lasted for four centuries, and its end is still debated. We show that the introduction of plague into Europe was not a one-time event, but rather repeated over a period of 15 y. We also show that the introduction of plague into Europe was not the consequence of the establishment of a permanent plague reservoir in Europe, but rather of the reintroduction of plague into European harbors from Asian reservoirs. Our results suggest that the end of the second plague pandemic was the consequence of the development of effective plague control measures. This study provides new insights into the history of plague, and it has implications for the development of effective control measures against the current COVID-19 pandemic.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and play a key role in the functioning of marine ecosystems. They are also a popular attraction in aquaria and are therefore exposed to the risk of viral infection. Here, we show that a virus is the most likely cause of the mass mortality of asteroids on the Pacific Coast of North America. This is the first report of a virus causing mass mortality of asteroids.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia in adults, and the prognosis of AML is poor. The identification of AML stem cells is important for the development of more efficient therapies. Here, we show that an antibody targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) can efficiently kill AML stem cells in xenograft models and that this antibody can also block IL-1 signaling. These results suggest that IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Thus, IL1RAP can be considered as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This study provides important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of genetic ancestries, with a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive picture of the history of Madagascar, which is a unique case in the Indian Ocean. It also provides a reference for future studies on the history of the Indian Ocean. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA (denoted AzuR). The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may help to reduce the time and cost of antibody development and may contribute to the global fight against the COVID-19 pandemic. Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, their assessments are subjective and categorical, and are not easily amenable to quantitative analysis. We show how to transform the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. We also discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data. Finally, we demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. This work is a step towards the development of a global network of “people as sensors” that can provide continuous and accurate information on crop status. This will be key to the development of early warning systems for agricultural production anomalies.

Language is a complex system that is thought to be supported by a number of different mechanisms. Here we propose a mechanism that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the order of the features that are integrated. This makes it suitable for the binding of linguistic features over time. We show that this mechanism can support memory for a number of different linguistic features, and that it can be used to integrate information over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change is poorly understood. We present the results of a global synthesis of soil respiration measurements, spanning nine biomes and 27 temperature manipulation studies. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important events in the history of life. It is also one of the most challenging problems in biology, as it is difficult to study in the laboratory. Here, we show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle, which is a key event in the evolution of many plant species, is also a major evolutionary challenge for the plastid genome. We show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on the plastid genome in a stepwise manner. Our findings have implications for the evolution of the plastid genome in general and for the evolution of the plant kingdom in particular.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the vulnerability of water-scarce regions to climate change. We use a high-resolution climate model to quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is timely given the current debate on the attribution of the 2015–2017 Cape Town drought. Our results are also relevant to other regions of the world that are vulnerable to multiyear rainfall deficits. We expect that the results of this work will be of interest to a broad audience

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has been a major advance in the field of materials science. The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear test, the “Trinity test,” is a unique event in the history of science.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use BchE, an O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess an O2-dependent enzyme, the major catalytic component of which is a diiron protein, AcsF. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the O2-dependent enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the O2-dependent enzyme. Neuroinflammation is a major feature of multiple sclerosis (MS) and experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), and it is well known to be associated with neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with the progression of MS. However, the precise cellular and molecular mechanisms of neuroinflammation in EAE remain unknown. In this study, we found that ASK1 is a critical regulator of neuroinflammation in EAE. We also found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in generating and maintaining disease, whereas ASK1 in astrocytes plays a greater proinflammatory role in the later stage. Our findings suggest that ASK1-mediated glial cell interactions are critical in the progression of EAE. We propose glial ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for EAE and other neuroinflammatory diseases. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and now includes the lowest calendar-year and 12-mo precipitation, the highest annual temperature, and the most extreme drought indicators on record. The extremely warm and dry conditions have led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that precipitation deficits in California were more than twice as likely to yield drought years if they occurred when conditions were warm. We find that although there has not been a substantial change in the probability of either negative or moderately negative precipitation anomalies in recent decades, the occurrence of drought years has been greater in the past two decades than in the preceding century. In addition, the probability that precipitation deficits co-occur with warm conditions and the probability that precipitation deficits produce drought have both increased. We conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California.

Autism is a complex disorder with a variety of symptoms, and the etiology is still not fully understood. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and may help to identify potential therapeutic targets. This study also provides a model system to study the role of forgetting in learning and memory. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling, and mutations in the pore-forming protein ORAI1 and the Ca2+ sensor STIM1 cause severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein ORAI1, which cause hematological abnormalities and myopathy. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease and Parkinson’s disease. In these diseases, the spread of aggregates is thought to be a major contributor to disease pathology. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on endocytosis and that this spreading is non–cell-autonomous. We also show that the spread of aggregates can be prevented by inhibiting endocytosis in vulnerable neurons. Finally, we show that the spread of aggregates is dependent on the release of aggregates from the cell of origin. These results provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many zoonotic viruses that cause disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of bats, which is a site for microbial community residence. This protein, named MTX, selectively inhibits the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTA4 hydrolysis and the generation of leukotriene B4 (LTB4), a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. MTX potently inhibited proinflammatory proteases to induce immune tolerance and maintain high stability. In mouse models, influenza A virus (IAV) infection and pathogenicity were exacerbated by MTX, but were reversed by interfering with the effects of MTX on LTA4H or exogenous LTB4 administration. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of LTA4H in the immune response

The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. One-carbon units are critical for cell growth, and SHMT is strongly up-regulated in cancer. Here we show that dual SHMT1/2 knockout blocks HCT-116 colon cancer tumor xenograft formation. We identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of human SHMT1/2, and show that they are effective cellular target engagers. We also show that formate generally rescues cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. We demonstrate that this effect is rooted in defective glycine uptake in DLBCL cell lines, rendering them uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. This work provides a foundation for the development of SHMT inhibitors as a therapeutic strategy for cancer. It also provides a rationale for targeting the glycine import pathway in DLBCL. This latter strategy is currently being explored in a clinical trial. The presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusion bodies in ALS is a phenomenon that has been observed in other neurodegenerative disorders. However, the presence of coaggregating proteins in ALS is unique in that they are supersaturated in motor neurons, but not in other tissues. This observation suggests that the presence of coaggregating proteins in ALS is a consequence of a specific set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a unique perspective on the role of protein aggregation in neurodegenerative disorders. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The photonic crystal system is predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The photonic crystal system is a promising platform for exploring many-body physics in 2D systems.
