The earliest known angiosperms are aquatic plants that lived and reproduced below the surface of the water. These plants are known from the Cretaceous, but the origin of this group is poorly understood. The research presented here focuses on Montsechia, a plant first recovered from the Cretaceous of the Pyrenees of Spain more than 100 y ago. Montsechia is an aquatic plant that is sister to Ceratophyllum, a plant that is also aquatic. Montsechia is the earliest known angiosperm that is aquatic and the earliest known angiosperm that reproduces below the surface of the water. The discovery of Montsechia raises questions about the very early diversification of the Ceratophyllum clade and the role of aquatic habitats in the early evolution of angiosperms. (Less)

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in molecular biology, and it is important to understand the evolution of the most prevalent human pathogen, the DNA virus B19V. We present 10 ancient B19V genomes, which are the oldest viral sequences to date. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the most prevalent B19V genotype. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. It also shows that ancient DNA is a valuable resource for studying the evolution of viruses. (Show more)

Sea level is rising around the world, and the rate of rise is accelerating. This is a result of a combination of natural processes and human activities. The acceleration is due to the combined effects of ice loss in Greenland and Antarctica and thermal expansion of the oceans. The acceleration is also due to the fact that the rate of sea level rise is increasing.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age for all adults, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950. This erosion of working-class life is not limited to pain, but is part of a more general erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950.

The ability to characterize the structure and dynamics of enzyme intermediates is a key goal in enzymology. Here, we demonstrate the utility of NMR-assisted crystallography in this area, providing a detailed picture of the fate of the leaving group in a reaction, and the role of the cofactor and side chains in the reaction pathway. This approach is applicable to a wide range of enzymes and reaction types, and is a powerful tool for mechanistic enzymology.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe disease with a high case fatality rate. There is a need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. Remdesivir (GS-5734) is a broad-spectrum inhibitor of RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRP) that has been shown to be effective against Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)-CoV. Here, we show that remdesivir is also effective against MERS-CoV, and that it can be used to treat MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. These data support the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial setting, and may also be applicable to other coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This is the first report of the use of remdesivir in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic relationships. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan, chitin, to its symbiotic bacterium, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm. This glycan is required for the maturation of the symbiotic organ, which is used for bioluminescence. We propose that this strategy is used by other hosts to regulate the activities of their associated symbionts. This work provides a new perspective on the regulation of the activities of symbionts and the role of glycans in the maintenance of animal–microbe relationships. (Read more)

This research has two main contributions. First, it shows that teachers can be trained to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. Second, it shows that this mindset can be sustained over time, and that it can be used to reduce suspension rates. These findings have implications for the future of school discipline, which is a major social issue in the United States.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA lesions that can interfere with the function of DNA. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of alkylation on transcription. We found that the transcription process is sensitive to the presence of alkylation. In particular, the transcription process is sensitive to the location of the alkylation. We also found that the transcription process is sensitive to the type of alkylation. These findings provide important mechanistic insights into the impact of alkylation on transcription. This work also provides a foundation for the development of strategies to mitigate the impact of alkylation on transcription. This work is expected to be useful for the development of cancer therapy and gene therapy.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe disease in humans. To better understand the mechanisms of MERS-CoV infection, we engineered MERS viruses with mutations that blocked sequential proteolysis, which is required for virus entry into cells. These mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These findings suggest that sequential proteolysis is a critical determinant of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is responsible for a large share of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the global population have the potential to make a significant contribution to reducing these emissions. However, the food system is also responsible for a large share of obesity and diet-related disease. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a large-scale catering operation can have a large impact on meal selection, with little impact on overall sales. This suggests that simple changes to catering practices could have a large impact on population health and the environment. The results also suggest that it may be possible to nudge people toward more sustainable diets without the need for complex interventions. This has implications for the design of future interventions to promote more sustainable diets.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. Here we use quantitative proteomics to show that the surfaceome is remodeled in a cell autologous fashion by oncogenes, and that this remodeling is harmonized by common biological themes. We complement the surfaceome data with whole cell glycoproteomics enabled by a recently developed technique called activated ion electron transfer dissociation. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a step toward a more complete understanding of the role of the cell surface in cancer. In the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented with minimal risk to electoral outcomes.

The SARS-CoV-2 virus has caused a global pandemic, with a need for a rapid understanding of the virus and its mechanisms of action. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique dimerization interface not seen in SARS-CoV-2 ORF7a. This structure provides a foundation for understanding the function of this protein and its potential for immune evasion. This work also provides a foundation for the development of antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia triggers cerebral edema in rats and that this is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the pathophysiology of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. The scientific enterprise is based on the idea that we can learn from data. This is a powerful idea, but it is not without its challenges. In this paper, we describe a set of challenges that arise when we have a large dataset and we are using sophisticated statistical methods to find associations. We describe some recent developments that address these challenges.

Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can directly induce the formation of functional vascular ECs (ETVECs) from human adult skin fibroblasts. ETV2-induced ETVECs exhibit EC characteristics in vitro and form mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in mice. Furthermore, ETVECs significantly improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. The role of STING in β-cell function and insulin secretion is unknown. Herein, we found that STING deficiency in β-cells caused glucose intolerance due to impaired GSIS. STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. STING deficiency also led to down-regulation of Pax6 protein levels and nuclear localization, which is essential for GSIS. These findings revealed a function of STING in the regulation of β-cell function and insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human and animal influenza. They are divided into subtypes, which are further divided into lineages. The evolution of these lineages is not well understood, but it is suspected that the packaging of the viral genome is involved. Here, we identified a mechanism that promotes the selective packaging of the viral genome. This mechanism is not widely conserved, which might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our results provide a better understanding of the packaging of the influenza A virus genome and might lead to the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is characterized by the formation of atherosclerotic lesions in blood vessels. The development of these lesions is a multistep process that is initiated by the activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes in vascular endothelial cells (ECs). The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. We found that exposure of cultured endothelial cells (ECs) to the atheroprone disturbed flow resulted in YAP/TAZ activation and translocation into EC nucleus to up-regulate the target genes, including cysteine-rich angiogenic inducer 61 (CYR61), connective tissue growth factor (CTGF), and ankyrin repeat domain 1 (ANKRD1). Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, in the United States, wildfire is now considered a major threat to the economy and environment. The economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades, and climate change has likely contributed to the increase in wildfire activity. In this study, we show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Our results highlight the importance of human activities in increasing wildfire activity and the need for policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards. (Less)

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a key factor in the success of urban policy.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecological method of pest control. However, their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the role of the virus in the host is still unclear. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the rate of viral production is rapid and the eclipse phase for ZIKV is short. We also estimate the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime. Finally, we assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection. This work can help in the design of future clinical trials. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a widespread phenomenon that is considered a key indicator of the health of coral reefs. However, the underlying causes of the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis remain poorly understood. Here, we show that the metabolic interactions between coral and symbionts are a key factor in the breakdown of the symbiosis. We demonstrate that the catabolism of amino acids during heat stress promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates, which in turn contributes to the breakdown of the symbiosis. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that protects the body from the environment. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the intestine leads to the development of intestinal tumors, which in turn trigger a regenerative response in the microbiome and lead to a loss of barrier function. We also show that inhibiting JNK signaling or depleting the microbiome can restore barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of the microbiome in cancer and for developing strategies to restore homeostasis in the intestine. They also suggest that the activity of JNK signaling may be a therapeutic target for treating intestinal tumors. This study also highlights the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. This is a major advance in our understanding of the role of JNK signaling in the intestine and in the regulation of the microbiome. It also suggests that the activity of JNK signaling may be a therapeutic target for treating intestinal tumors.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Although the majority of breast cancers are hormone receptor–positive, a small percentage of patients are resistant to endocrine therapy. In this study, we found that the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 was expressed in a subset of breast cancers that were resistant to endocrine therapy. We also found that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab was more effective than treatment with either the antibody or the chemotherapy drug paclitaxel alone in eradicating the tumors. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the start of accelerated deglaciation is still a matter of debate. We show that a series of volcanic eruptions, exactly at the start of deglaciation, led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which plausibly triggered a series of climate changes that affected the Southern Hemisphere.

Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, freshwater fisheries are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also find that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. Our data can be used to inform conservation and management efforts to protect both biodiversity and food security. This is particularly important in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors, such as agriculture and hydropower. Our results also highlight the need for improved management of inland fisheries, which are often understudied and underfunded.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. Due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited. For achieving durable and high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries, the development of negative electrode materials exhibiting a large capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water is crucial. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. In the past decade, we have learned that the adult CNS is capable of regenerating, but the molecular mechanisms that mediate this process are largely unknown. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult CNS. This discovery unites disparate forms of regeneration and reveals a previously unknown form of intrinsic regeneration in the adult nervous system. Our study also reveals a previously unknown form of activity-dependent ectopic axon growth in the same neuron type, which may be a powerful platform for gene discovery in the study of neuronal regeneration. This study also suggests that the adult nervous system may be more plastic than previously thought.

Recombination is the process by which genetic material is exchanged between homologous DNA sequences, and it is essential for the proper functioning of the genome. In humans and mice, hotspots of recombination are located in the promoter regions of genes, and cold regions are located in the interior of genes. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination in the genome of a flowering plant, and we find that the distribution of hotspots is similar to that in yeast and mice. This suggests that the pattern of recombination in the genome of a flowering plant may reflect ancient and conserved eukaryotic mechanisms.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in functional connectivity reflecting the activity of a large number of brain regions. The analysis of these fluctuations has led to the identification of a small number of reproducible networks, which are assumed to reflect the organization of the brain. However, the validity of this assumption has not been tested. Here, we show that the dominant network in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network, but that this assumption is not valid in Parkinson’s disease. We also show that the dominant network in healthy subjects is associated with reduced metabolic activity, which is reversed by dopaminergic therapy. This work provides a direct test of the validity of the resting state network hypothesis. It also provides a method for assessing the functional significance of the brain, which can be used to monitor the effects of disease and treatment.

The 5′ cap structure of messenger RNA (mRNA) is known to regulate translation. Here we report the discovery of a second 5′ cap structure in eukaryotes, which we call the 5′ NAD+ cap. We show that this cap is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. We also show that the 5′ NAD+ cap is not found on pre-mRNAs, suggesting that it is produced cotranscriptionally. The 5′ NAD+ cap may regulate mRNA stability and/or translation. This discovery adds to our understanding of the diversity of 5′ RNA modifications in eukaryotes and the mechanisms that regulate mRNA stability. It also raises the possibility that the 5′ NAD+ cap could be involved in the regulation of gene expression. (Show more)

The epigenetic regulation of gene expression is a promising target for the treatment of diabetes complications. We studied the DNA-methylation profile of blood cells from people with diabetes, and compared it with that of healthy controls. We found that DNA-me differences at specific loci persist for several years in people with diabetes, and that these loci are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory and suggest that DNA-me may be a target for the treatment of diabetes complications. This study also provides a resource for future studies on the role of DNA-me in diabetes complications. The role of a protein in cancer is determined by its expression level, function, and interaction with other proteins. We have identified a protein, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), that is highly expressed in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) and is associated with poor prognosis. We show that FSIP1 deficiency in TNBC cells impairs drug sensitivity and that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, which is a key component of the autophagy machinery. FSIP1 deficiency promotes autophagy, enhances AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreases mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. These findings uncover a role of FSIP1 in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This study also highlights the importance of the AMPK–autophagy–mTOR–Wnt/β-catenin pathway in TNBC. This study may also aid in the development of a drug combination therapy for TNBC. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a complex disorder that affects many aspects of the individual’s life. The present study shows that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, we found that the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence and in the regulation of the psychological symptoms of the disease. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a rationale for the development of new therapeutic strategies for alcohol dependence.

The production of volatile compounds is a fundamental process in many plants, and the identification of the enzymes responsible for their biosynthesis is a major step forward in understanding the mechanisms of plant aroma production. Here, we report the identification of a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes the biosynthesis of a wide range of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This pathway is distinct from that of other plants, and the identification of this pathway in tomato fruit is a major step forward in understanding the mechanisms of plant aroma production. This pathway may also be applicable to other species of the tomato clade. The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key hub for the formation of spatial maps in the hippocampus. The organization of its neurons is still debated, with some studies suggesting that the different cell types are anatomically segregated, while others suggest that they are mixed. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that the different cell types are mixed, but that they are also segregated in some cases. These data provide a more complete picture of the organization of the MEC and its relation to the hippocampus. They also provide a model for the design of future experiments. Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FT is required for flowering of both host and parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also shows that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–dodder interactions. This is the first study to show that FTs can function as an interplant flowering signal in a host–parasite interaction. This study may help to understand the evolution of flowering in plants and the evolution of parasitism. It may also help to understand the evolution of flowering in the parasitic dodder.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system. The underlying cause of this disorder is unknown, but it is thought to involve a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized system within the dopamine-containing nigral system that is likely to be affected in Parkinson’s disease and other disorders. This system, termed “striosome–dendron bouquets,” is formed by tightly intertwined striosomes and dopamine-containing dendrites. We suggest that these specialized integrative units are critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This system may also be relevant to the control of movement and motivation. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the function of the dopamine systems in health and disease. They also suggest that the striosome–dendron bouquets may be a target for therapeutic intervention.

We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rated their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. SAN cells (SANCs) are able to adjust heart rate to meet hemodynamic demand by integrating the membrane clock and the Ca2+ clock. Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, and its beneficial effects on plant resistance against abiotic and biotic stresses have been well documented. However, the role of Si in mediating insect herbivore resistance has not been explored. Here, we show that Si pretreatment enhances rice resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest, and that this effect is mediated by priming of jasmonate (JA)-mediated defense responses. These results suggest that Si may be used as a biocontrol agent to enhance insect herbivore resistance. (Read more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is still poorly understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the function of macrophages, which are the main immune cells in the body. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. This study provides a new perspective on the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism and opens up new avenues for the development of therapeutic strategies for diseases involving ether lipid metabolism. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the speed of adaptation. The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in the field of plant biology. This is due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Herein, we report the successful delivery of siRNAs to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for the successful delivery of siRNAs to plants. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a step forward in the field of plant biology and will be of interest to the broader scientific community.

The world’s largest freshwater lakes are vulnerable to coastal eutrophication, which can threaten the health of the entire water body. In this study, we show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to large lakes, especially in the nearshore zone. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small watersheds, as they can have disproportionately large impacts on coastal eutrophication. This approach could be applied to other large lakes and could be extended to other water bodies, such as estuaries and coastal seas, where coastal eutrophication is a growing concern. Our findings have implications for the management of water quality in the Anthropocene.

We study the dynamics of a chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “rare event” behavior that is observed in many physical systems, and it is a consequence of the fact that the environment is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We discuss the implications of our results for the design of catalytic systems that are able to operate in environments that are biased toward rare events. We also discuss the implications of our results for the design of catalytic systems that are able to operate in environments that are biased toward rare events.

The mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Ab encephalitis can change the intrinsic microcircuitry of the brain, which can then predispose brain dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities. This work offers mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab, which may be relevant to the development of new therapies. This work also highlights the importance of understanding the effects of disease on the brain’s intrinsic microcircuitry, which can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. This may be relevant to the development of new therapies.

The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event, and it is important to understand the history of abrupt warming in the past to better understand the potential impacts of the current warming. Here, we present a study of an abrupt warming event that occurred ∼304 Ma during a glacial period. We show that this event was accompanied by a global-scale, negative carbon isotope excursion and a doubling of atmospheric CO2. We also show that this warming was linked to an increase in nutrient fluxes and thermocline stratification, which may have contributed to the extinction of many species. These results provide insights into the potential impacts of the current rapid warming and may help to inform mitigation strategies. (Less)

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production is certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO). However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we use a comprehensive dataset of RSPO-certified and noncertified oil palm plantations in Indonesia, as well as annual remotely sensed metrics of tree cover loss and fire occurrence, to evaluate the impact of certification on deforestation and fire. Our results suggest that certification reduced deforestation in oil palm plantations. Nevertheless, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. The exocyst complex is a protein complex that is essential for the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. The exocyst complex is composed of 10 evolutionarily conserved subunits. The function of the exocyst complex is conserved from yeast to humans, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. The study also offers a potential explanation for the evolutionarily conserved function of the N terminus of the EXO70 protein. Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the genetic basis of sex determination is a major area of study. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, which can be male- or female-determining. In some species, multiple alleles at a sex determination locus can produce more than two genotypic sexes, and in others, the sex determination locus can be lost. Here we investigate the effects of multiple alleles at a sex determination locus on the evolution of secondary sexual characteristics. We find that multiple alleles at a sex determination locus can produce modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, and that the introgression of a new sex determination allele can produce additional axes of variation for secondary sexual characteristics. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of multiple alleles at sex determination loci. (Read more)

The retina is challenged by the accumulation of bisretinoids, a class of lipofuscin precursors, that photodegrade into damaging species. We show that the Fe chelator deferiprone decreases the photodegradation of the bisretinoid A2E in the presence of light and reduces the loss of photoreceptor cells in a mouse model of retinal degeneration. These findings suggest that Fe levels in the retina may impact the accumulation of bisretinoids and the loss of photoreceptor cells. This interpretation is supported by the demonstration that the Fe chelator decreases the oxidation of A2E in the presence of Fenton chemistry products. These results provide insight into the role of Fe in the retina and may lead to the development of new therapies for retinal degeneration. Predators are the main drivers of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning, and thus, their evolution is of great interest to ecology and evolution. However, the evolution of predator morphology is often constrained by the need to capture a wide range of prey types. In this study, we show that the evolution of predator morphology can be highly flexible, and that predators can evolve to specialize on new prey types. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the evolution of predator morphology, and for the functioning of food webs. They also have implications for our understanding of the evolution of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning.

The evolution of the human hand is one of the most important and enigmatic aspects of human evolution. The study of the hand is complicated by the fact that the hand is the most mobile part of the body and, as a consequence, the hand is the most difficult part of the body to preserve. The study of the hand in the fossil record is further complicated by the fact that the hand is the most complex part of the body and, as a consequence, the hand is the most difficult part of the body to study. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. One-carbon units are critical for cell growth, and SHMT is strongly up-regulated in cancer. Here we show that dual SHMT1/2 knockout blocks HCT-116 colon cancer tumor xenograft formation. We identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of human SHMT1/2, and show that they are effective cellular target engagers. We also show that formate generally rescues cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. We demonstrate that this effect is rooted in defective glycine uptake in DLBCL cell lines, rendering them uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. This work provides a foundation for the development of SHMT inhibitors as a therapeutic strategy for cancer. It also provides a rationale for targeting the glycine import pathway in DLBCL. This latter strategy is currently being explored in a clinical trial. This study shows that deforestation can have negative effects on people’s diets. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The results also highlight the need to consider the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries.

Modern agriculture is a major contributor to global food production, but it is also a major cause of soil degradation. The mechanization of agriculture has increased the capacity of farm machinery, but it has also increased the weight of vehicles, which has led to subsoil compaction. We show that the weight of modern farm machinery has increased subsoil compaction risk to the point that it now affects 20% of arable land. We hypothesize that this trend is a consequence of the increasing size of sauropods, which roamed the Earth before the development of modern agriculture. Our findings suggest that the roaming of these giants may have had a similar effect on land productivity as modern farm vehicles.
